node.text:
CW: violence against intersex people

I spoke with @saifaemerges from @intersexjusticeproject about the intersex justice movement and the action they are planning in NYC tomorrow to end non consensual intersex surgeries. Intersex rights are human rights! #EndIntersexSurgery

node.text: I moderated a discussion between performance artist @cassilsartist, curator @tinariversryan, and @vvtle of #ForFreedoms on the inherent biases and inequities of the NFT market, as well as potential solutions for artists in this space. A percentage of funds raised from the sale of @whitemaleartistnft will go towards a BIPOC and trans/non-binary fund for #ForFreedoms.

node.text: Celebrating all of the LGBTQIA+ people out there. I love and need you so much. I am so, so proud of you. Rooting for you always.

node.title: You Are an Everyday Miracle: Pride Affirmation

node.text: I speak with queer Jamaican-American author @rodriquesque about his new novel “All the Water I’ve Seen is Running.” We discuss migration, trauma, desire, language, and more! Please order a copy of this gorgeous debut from an indie book store and request it in your local libraries!

node.text: #ad My hair has always been a vehicle for my self-expression. Before I even had the language to express what I was, style was how I claimed space, communicated with the world, and let people know who I was on my own terms. Thank you to @johnfriedaus for inviting me to share my story in support of the important work of @GLSEN , an organization working to end bullying of LGBTQ+ students. #PrideThatDemandsAttention #takepride

node.title: Expressing Myself With My Hair Color

node.text: I speak with @iamtazme about the queer nightlife they curate with @thedeathofglitter in Cape Town, South Africa. We discuss what it means to celebrate queerness in a world structured against it and art as political protest. What resonates with you?

node.title: Queer South African Nightlife with Tazme

node.text:
I speak with my personal coach @moryfontanez about our collective crisis of imagination, overcoming the disconnect between who we are and what this world tells us to be, and harnessing the power of our intuition. Please let us know what resonates and follow Mory for more wisdom!

To support the COVID fundraiser for the West Bengali trans community mentioned in this live (link in bio)

node.text:
We have been here for thousands of years. What is new is the division of billions of people into one of two categories. Ending the gender binary helps everyone. Everyone deserves the right to determine their own gender. 

From my @onecolorado virtual keynote.

node.title: Trans People Aren't New, Transphobia Is

node.text:
With the onslaught of anti-trans legislation all around us, it's important to remember that we as trans and gender non-conforming people come from a powerful and sacred legacy. For us: fabulosity is a political praxis of self-worth in the face of attempted erasure and criminalization. 

excerpt from a talk for @pointsourceyouth !

node.text: I speak about the history of politicizing body hair, my own journey to embracing my body hair, and moving from self acceptance to self compassion. Thank you @fur_you 💘

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by ALOK on August 11, 2021 tagging @lasaia_wade, @itsbrandyncross, @katchsilva, @thebaejazelle, and @iamelsz. May be an image of 4 people, people sitting and indoor.

node.text:
Growing up my mom used to insist that we all come together at the table for dinner. She would play her favorite jazz and for at least thirty minutes every evening we would suspend time to the sweet serenades of Ella Fitzgerald, Louis Armstrong, Billie Holiday. There are so many albums I know by taste. 

I inherited my mom’s love of hosting. I love bringing my friends together for a meal. Small talk is an oxymoron. Let’s talk big, language is too beautiful to confine to pleasantry. Be rogue. We, like the sauce on our dresses, spill. We overflow, can’t / won’t fit into categories, let alone words. What’s your gender? A conversation that never ends. Where are you from? The dinner table. 

Ambiance never felt like an apt enough word to describe it. It’s not just the things around us — it’s about how those things elicit something inside of us. Like stage lightning, the candles bring us into being. I think people look the most ravishing in that glow. The cinema of friends becoming strangers, secrets singing like the crickets outside. Here: night is our friend. Darkness is our home. 

The table was my first stage. It’s where I learned the anatomy of an argument. Studied wit like a graduate student (so I could keep up). Learned how to tell jokes, and be the butt of them. The table is where I started to speak myself into existence. Had my first audience. Over time. And with the right people. “This is what I believe” becomes “this is who I am.” 

I want to take you out to dinner & let you figure it out. Listen to all the things you aren’t supposed to say. Ask the wrong questions. Fumble through it: the discourtesy of being different people with different scars. Identity is an invitation to a table somewhere — find it. Who are you outside of what you’ve been told? 

My favorite part of my birthday last month was the meals together. We seasoned that shit with our tears, peppered it with expletives. There is a Yelp review somewhere out there talking about noise we take full responsibility for. I found myself listening, just watching thinking — damn. How lucky I am to have found family in my friends.

📸 @katchsilva

node.text:
When I die I want the photo they use for my memorial to be a portrait of me with my friends. My friends loved me before I could love myself. Taught me how to exist in this world unapologetically as a brown transfeminine person. Who I am is an amalgam of their care, critique, conversations. Meaning — I would not be here without them today. My friends are the greatest romances of my life. 

And friendship, like all the most precious and sacred things in the world, so often gets disappeared from the narrative. We hear so many love stories about romantic partners, but what about the friends who helped process the breakup? When I read a great author I want to know who they hung out with when they had writers block. Or a philosopher — who they called when their heart was broken? There have been times in my life where I have felt like giving up, and it’s my friends who remind me why I keep going. I am because we are. 

For my 30th birthday I hired a wedding photographer to shoot film portraits of me and my friends. I wanted to leave evidence: we were here in a world that said we shouldn’t be. We were glamorous and contradictory, naive and brilliant at the same time. We weren’t meant to find each other, but we did. Which means impossible is merely a suggestion. And that friendship is the miracle.

The photographer asked my friends to tell me what they wished for me in my new decade. These people know my doubts, my apprehensions, and inconsistencies. And they said the things I needed to hear. Gave me permission to grow. So many words — one big, big feeling. I am not alone. Even in my loneliness, I am not alone. 

📸 @katchsilva 
makeup @itsbrandyncross

node.text: @ocean_vuong says that he wants to love more than death can harm. So do I. What if we were to bring the sensibility of poetry — with its commitment to beauty and meaning — to the ways we relate each other? What if we suspend the need to know, and instead oriented around a need to love? An economy of love is so much more durable than fear. Care, more eternal than anything else I have ever felt.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by ALOK on August 09, 2021 tagging @mariememusic, @nooworks, @katmaconie, and @funkymaharani. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
At breakfast with @mariememusic we found ourselves just tearing up, overwhelmed by the beauty of language, and each other.

Both of us grew up in places that told us we were fundamentally wrong — unloveable even. But through our own journeys we asked: Why would we let the various systems that are predicated on our disappearance, evaluate us? We had to develop another algorithm, another way of existing in the world. And in our spiritual journeys we came to the same conclusion: self-validation. Refusing the callous embrace of legitimacy or normalcy, and opting instead for something more honest, gnarly, eternal: being. Soul first, vulnerable, porous, being. 

Recently I have been noticing so much wonder around me. I’m chewing on lunch like “damn, this taste is the sweetest medicine.” I see an outfit that inspires me and I shout with glee! Say thank you! To the fashionist@s who paint these bleak cityscapes with color. I am joyous. Not ephemeral happiness, unshakeable joy. 

There are rough days, there is loneliness, disappointment, pain. But the suffering, it is visiting. My natural orientation is toward mirth, connection, the quiet whisper of the wind on my hairy arms. I want so badly to be here. And I’m so glad I am. 

It’s been a long time coming, but I feel so rooted on this earth. Something in me has transformed and I feel so steadfast in my truth and my conviction in love. I see miracles all around me. I keep magnetizing the connections I was looking for all along.

Is this what it feels like to be in your thirties? I spent so much of the last decade trying to prove something. I outsourced my power, waiting for approval. Now I approve of myself, and that’s enough. I believe in myself, and my worth, and my art, and that is enough. And in practicing self-acceptance, I unlocked so much space for compassion for others. There is no separation: my self forgiveness drives me every day to wake up and ask: How do I bring beauty to the sidewalk today? Concretely: where can I harvest love today? 

That’s what fuels me now: love. It feels so much more durable, so much more potent, so much more enduring than anything I have ever known. I love & need you.

node.text:
As a gender non-conforming person I’m used to people distancing themselves from me. Sometimes when I take a seat on the bus or a train, the person next to me gets up and leaves. I’ve had people tell me they won’t walk next to me in public because they don’t want to deal with people staring at us. I’ve become so accustomed to daily displays of cruelty that it’s just become my normal. 

What I’m not used to is people defending me. 

@papadontpreachbyshubhika the designer of this beautiful look lost a ton of followers after featuring me of people who were disgusted by my appearance. In response, they posted a message of support and bid the haters farewell!

I was so moved. So many fashion brands use people like me as mood boards and inspirations, rarely models. They covet our energy, and forget to protect our dignity. For this kind of public affirmation to come from an Indian woman-owned fashion brand means the world and I just want to say thank you from the bottom of my heart.

I truly hope we can create a more inclusive fashion industry where all bodies are celebrated for their beauty. This is not just for gender non-conforming people, this is for everyone. We are all stunted by a narrow, one-dimensional beauty. Free beauty from the binary. Let it proliferate. 

To our peers in the fashion industry: take note.🥺❤️ #degenderfashion

node.text:
Book Report: The Heart of Whiteness: Normal Sexuality and Race in America, 1880-1940 by Dr. Julian Carter (Duke University Press, 2007)

1. Please tag/share this important history 
2. To learn more order the book from an indie book store (link in bio)
3. For 700+ additional book recommendations follow me on Goodreads (link in bio)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by ALOK on August 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'top of skull chin nipples navel crotch how "normal" became a code word for "white:" a eugenic history fingertips bottom of knee floor'.

Photo by ALOK on August 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'ONLY HEALTHY SEED MUST BE SOWN! LIVE, LOVE and MARRY WISELY CHECKTHE UNFITNESS RESULT SOUND CHILDREN The language of "normal" has historically been used to disguise racist values as benign and politically neutral. In the context of the US, normal was infused by eugenics (a racist, pseudoscientific strategy to "improve the race"). Normality is not about objective facts, rather it makes specific claims about the superiority of particular traits.'.

Photo by ALOK on August 08, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Take for example the construction of the two statues "Normman" and "Norma" designed in 1939 to represent the average US-American male and female, despite the fact that almost no one embodied these proportions. A contest was held to find the ideal woman who most closely resembled this sculpture. Eugenicists deployed the language of "normal" to cultivate the white race and discipline people into particular appearances and ways of living in order to become the most "advanced" civilization on Earth. They cared more about presumed perfection than the poetry (hairiness, fatness, gender non- conformity) of actual bodies.'.

Photo by ALOK on August 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'RELEASE THE STRANGLE HOLD OF HEREDITARY DISEASE AND UNFITNESS In particular, "normal" became the code word to describe "sexual fitness," or the ability to align one's sexual practices with the interests of the race. Racist evolutionary thought regarded reproduction as the primary mode for racial development. In the early 20th century, monogamous, heterosexual, intra-racial marriage was upheld as the only legitimate mode of sexuality specifically to foster the growth of the white population. White people were taught that they were responsible for civilization and that practicing sexual elf-restraint would ensure the continued progression and advancement of the next generation.'.

Photo by ALOK on August 08, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'This self-restraint was in contrast to the alleged sexual decadence of 'savage" peoples who were depicted as merely motivated by primal sexual urges, incapable of "civilized" romance and family structures. During this time, we see white anxieties coalesce around the figure of the "degenerate" "queer" who was seen as a remnant of weakness and primitivism in the white race. Queer people were pathologized as having NEED a form of "sexual disability, preventing them from evolving YOU into appropriate "modern" heterosexuality. Pay IF GAY YOU' YOUR COUNTRY'.

Photo by ALOK on August 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Exclusive heterosexuality was marketed as essential for national stability and racial progress. This normative standard conferred legitimacy and status such that later in the century one of the primary ways that (Irish, Italian, Jewish, etc.) immigrants were able to assimilate into the nation was by adopting heteronormativity (assuming traditional gender roles and family structures). As Carter argues, "aligning oneself with normal heterosexuality had the effect of performing one's alignment with ideal whiteness" (98)'.

Photo by ALOK on August 08, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and text that says 'Despite the fact that no one can actually achieve this illusive idea of "normal," perceived proximity to normality awards legitimacy and power. This is why racialized people might respond to loss of status from racism by reinforcing traditional gender norms. This is also why gender non- conforming people experience such profound cruelty.'.
Photo by ALOK on August 08, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, book and text that says 'Ûhef HEART Normal Sexuality Race in 1880- WHITENESS JULIAN B. CARTER Duke University Press (2007)'.
Photo by ALOK on August 08, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
“Cynicism postures itself as some sort of moral or ethical authority. The voice of reason comes into the chat and they'll dismiss those of us who speak about the power of creativity as just idealistic, naive, far fetched, and foolish because of the severity of the present. And I always just respond with the prolific and kind of prophetic words of Gloria Anzaldúa who says “nothing happens in the real world until it happens first in the images in our own head”, and I think what she was trying to articulate with that is that there's this way in which Western secular technoscience has made us obsessed with physical form as if things aren't spiritual and energetic before they become physical form. I'm thinking here, about imaginal cells, when caterpillars become butterflies, they have cells that essentially are called imaginal cells that are the transformative potential that catalyze that transformation. I'm thinking a lot about that potentiality in each of us.” 
⁣⁣
My podcast episode with @for.the.wild is out everywhere you listen to your podcasts (or at the link in my bio). It’s one of the most thoughtful interviews I’ve ever done and I flesh out my philosophy of beauty and love. I’d really like for you to listen. I hope it offers some solace and affirmation. Let me know what you think! Love & need you x

Let’s create a world where people are valued for who they are, not who they should be.  1) Please share/tag this important history 2) Order these books from an indie book store for more information (link in bio) 3) Follow me on goodreads for the full text of this report along with 700+ book recommendations (link in bio)
